Detailed Description

Objects of this class parses the given arguments on then commandline and stores their values in given variables.

The general grammar for a command line is defined by argv[0] [options] [tail].

In the example cp -r src1 src2 dest , argv[0] is cp, the option given is -r the tail (of length 3) is src1 src2 destde.

The tailpart can be forced to have a minimum length.

If the handler is run in the so called lazyMode (not recommended), the parser acts a bit different. One could write for instance

cp src1 -r src2 dest

or

cp src1 src2 dest -r

and the commandline will (probably) be parsed correctly. This feature is not very well tested, and therefore not recommended to use.

Options can have different types as specified in the enum value_t, and each type excluding presentVal supports the possibility of more than one value. The values of an option must immediately follow the option tag. Example:

prog -s ''first string'' string2 src dest.

Here the -s flag is a string option (stringVal ), specified two have two values. The first value becomes ''first string'', since it's enclosed in quotes. The second value is ''string2''. The possibility to compound values with quotes applies only to stringVal or tail items.

By default, the handler always specifies the options

  • -h/--help presentVal option. The parse() method calls printUsage(cout) and exits with returncode 0.
  • v/--version presentVal option. The parse() method calls printVersion(cout) and exits with returncode 0.
  • p/--property stringVal option with one value. Used to give the user the possibility to specify a propertyfile. If the environment variable MC2_PROPERTIES is defined as a filename, this name is used by default. Otherwise the default filename is mc2.prop in the current path.

A number of presentVal options or can be specified in the same token. For example

prog -hv

will print usage an version for prog and the exit. This feature naturally applies only to presentVal options.

The help feature of the class utilizes the environment variable COLUMNS. If it's defined and exported from the parent shell, all help texts is nicely formatted in the terminal window.

Member Enumeration Documentation

enum CommandlineOptionHandler::value_t
 

The possible value types for the options.

Enumeration values:
characterVal  The value of this command line option is a single character.

The optionValue-pointer must point to a "char".

stringVal  The value of this command line option is a string.

The optionValue-pointer must point to a "char*".

presentVal  The value of this command line option is true if present, false otherwise.

The default value must be 'T' (for true) and 'F' (for false) and the optionValue-pointer must point to a "bool".

integerVal  The value of this command line option is an integer.

The optionValue-pointer must point to a "int".

uint32Val  The value of this command line option is an unsigned 32-bit integer.

The optionValue-pointer must point to a "uint32".

floatVal  The value of this command line option is a float.

The optionValue-pointer must point to a "float64".

singleChoiceVal  The value of this option is uint32, but each possible value also has it's own long option that works as a presentVal.

Member Function Documentation

void CommandlineOptionHandler::addOption (  const char *  shortName,
const char *  longName,
value_t  valueType,
uint32  nbrValues,
void *  optionValue,
const char *  defaultValue,
const char *  helpText
) 
 

Add an option to the list of possible options.

Parameters:
shortName The shortname of this option (e.g. -h ). No other added option may have the same shortName. Set to empty string if no shortName shall be added.
longName The long name of this option (e.g. --help ). No other option may have the same longName.
valueType The type of the variable where the value will be stored.
nbrValues The number of values for this option.
optionValue Pointer to the variable where the value will be stored.
defaultValue The defaultvalue of this option.
helpText Help that will be displayed to the user.
See also:
value_t

Option

template<class InIt>
void CommandlineOptionHandler::addSingleChoiceOption (  const MC2String &  shortName,
InIt  firstLongName,
InIt  lastLongName,
uint32 *  optionValue,
uint32  defaultValue,
const char *  helpText
) 
 

Adds a singleChoiceOption, which is a lot like a uint32option except that each defined value has it's own longname.

The longnames are defined by a pair of MC2String or char* where the first value is the longname (including the '--' prefix) and the second is a short help string for the option.

Parameters:
shortName The shortname (e.g. -h ). No other added option may have the sameshortName. May be empty.
firstLongName Forward iterator referring to the first pair that defines a longName.
lastLongName Forward iterator representing the end (i.e. one past the last) of the longname pairs.
optionValue pointer to the variable that will receive the chosen value.
defaultValue The default value of this option.
helpText The helptext for the total option.

Definition at line 635 of file CommandlineOptionHandler.h.

bool CommandlineOptionHandler::parse (  bool  handleErrors = true  ) 
 

Parse the command line.

Parameters:
handleErrors If true parse() will complain about unknown options, etc.
Returns:
True on success, oterwise false. If false is returned, the parser has failed to interpret the commandline, and nothing can be expected from the results. Cleanup and exit is recommended.
